qas.question: What is a group labeled when the element 1 is primitive?
What group is isomorphic to cyclic groups?

answers.text: Any cyclic group with n elements

qas.question: What example of cyclic group satisfies the express of zn = 1?

answers.text: the group of n-th complex roots of unity

qas.question: A cyclic group without n elements is considered what?
What element is not primitive in groups Z/nZ?
What are groups called when element 1 is not primitive?
What rotation results in multiplying but n?
What are numbers on an irregular n-gon?

context: In the groups Z/nZ introduced above, the element <b4_0>1<b4_0/> is primitive, so these groups are <a0_0><b5_0>cyclic<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Indeed, each element is expressible as a sum all of whose terms are 1. <a1_0>Any cyclic group with n elements<a1_0/> is <b3_0>isomorphic<b3_0/> to this group. A second example for cyclic groups is <a2_0>the group of n-th complex roots of unity<a2_0/>, given by complex numbers z satisfying zn = 1. These numbers can be visualized as the <b7_0>vertices<b7_0/> on a regular n-gon, as shown in blue at the right for n = 6. The group operation is multiplication of complex numbers. In the picture, multiplying with z corresponds to <b6_0>a counter-clockwise rotation by 60°<b6_0/>. Using some field theory, the group Fp× can be shown to be cyclic: for example, if p = 5, 3 is a generator since 31 = 3, 32 = 9 ≡ 4, 33 ≡ 2, and 34 ≡ 1.
